Title: 1966 Chevrolet C10 Rat Rod
Key Facts: ['#NosferatuRatRod', 'Built by Jim Hall at Iron Customs, Indiana', 'Finished by Bodie Stroud at BS Industries']
interior:
Yes, the doors do open and, no, you won’t have to climb in through the roof.
That said, if you’re 7’2”, a bit arthritic or you’ve been overdoing it on the pies, this may not be the ideal car for you, although the steering wheel can be removed to make ingress and egress a trifle easier.
It’s a bit of a squeeze, but once you’re in, you’ll find the seats to be enveloping, supportive and more comfortable than they look. Somehow, we don’t imagine you’ll be doing any inter-continental journeys in it.
The Hurst gear lever, steering wheel, handbrake and other controls are all heavy-duty items and look as indestructible as the rest of this urban road warrior.
The dashboard features a full set of instruments and dials, and all the switches, knobs and toggles are handily labelled.
Once you’re in situ and ready to rumble, there’s a fairly simple starting procedure to follow.
The vendor describes it thus: “It’s not difficult at all, really just that you need to pull the choke fully out. As long as you do that, it starts very easily, but on half choke, not at all! Let it run rough for just a few seconds after it’s caught and then lose most of the choke. You can then lose all the choke pretty soon after that and it settles down to a lovely smooth big-block idle.”
We followed his instructions to the letter and, sure enough, the car responded faithfully and as described.
As far as we’re aware, everything does what it’s supposed to do.
Background:
For decades the Chevrolet C/K series served as the backbone of the marque’s line-up of trucks, panel vans and pick-ups, becoming virtually synonymous with a 1960’s American blue-collar zeitgeist that manifested itself in countless movies and other cultural expressions.
The C10 was available in various equipment variants, including a basic version, a custom model and a sportier Cheyenne version.
Eagle-eyed observers among you may have noticed something intriguingly different about this one.
If you can’t quite put your finger on it, here’s a clue: it’s utterly bonkers in every conceivable way – plus some others that aren’t really conceivable.
Overview:
We get to see a lot of cars here at our Oxfordshire HQ.
Great ones, rare ones, fast ones, expensive ones, interesting ones, weird ones, old ones, big ones, small ones….you get the picture.
But we’ve never encountered anything quite like this one.
This creation started out in life in 1966 as a Chevy C-10 pick-up.
Then it was worked on by Jim Hall, of Iron Customs in Indiana. He chopped the body and then sold the car as an incomplete project to its next owner, an LA hot-rod builder by the name of Brian Davis, who got the build to about 80% completion.
He then handed over the final 20% of the build and customisation to Bodie Stroud, of BS Industries, who is a bona fide rockstar among custom car builders. His work has featured on Jay Leno’s Garage and he’s built cars for stars including Johnny Depp. BS Industries tackled the steering, brakes, fuel system and, well, lots of other stuff.
Once finished, the car was known and liveried as ‘Nosferatu’.
Shortly afterwards, early in 2016, the car came to the attention of the British co-originator of the legendary Carmageddon gaming brand, who is also the CEO and co-founder of the company behind it - Stainless Games Ltd.
He is Patrick Buckland, creator of Carmageddon, and he saw an opportunity to use the car as a promotional tool for the 2016 launch of Carmageddon: Max Damage.
And that’s why this fire-breathing sinister-looking automotive behemoth is wrapped in the livery you see before you today. You can see two renderings of the in-game model that their artists created for the game, it's quite impressive.
Amazingly, the car was road legal in the US (which might give you some hope that similar status could be possible here – with a few modifications, of course), and there are photos of Patrick's wife driving it in rush-hour Los Angeles traffic, an accomplishment for which there really cannot be too much praise.
The car featured at a number of video game trade shows in the US before being shipped back to the UK, where it turned out at a few promotional events and, at one point, made an appearance at Goodwood, where it attracted nearly as many curious onlookers as an Aston Martin Valkyrie parked nearby.
It’s undoubted ability to command attention is partly a consequence of its striking appearance, but mostly down to the sound it makes when you fire-up the mahoosive 454 Chevy big-block engine.
That’s 7.4-litres of good ol’ grunt under your right foot and ample proof of the old adage that there’s simply no replacement for displacement.
The sound you hear first is the fuel pump, which sounds more powerful than a small saloon car on its own.
Then you hear the red air intake flaps banging open and shut like privy doors at a curried shellfish festival.
Next, and please make sure you’re standing well back from the eight mortar-like upturned exhausts when this happens, an apocalyptic cacophony of explosions, roars, shrieks, wails, pops and barks erupts like an electrical storm over the Eiger or a too-close-for-comfort supernova.
And when we say the exhausts are mortar-like, Patrick tells us that a carefully placed sausage was launched from one at Goodwood and may now be orbiting Jupiter.
{Health & Safety note: please make sure that the exhausts are covered when the car is not in use – a stone or coin dropped through the manifold would not be good news for the engine.}
It was then in storage for many years, before Patrick bought it from his own company in 2021 with a view to getting it road legal in the UK.
That plan never quite materialised and he is only selling now because this thing takes up an awful lot of garage space and really deserves to be used more often.
exterior:
Well, the outside of this car is bespoke, hand-crafted, customised and unique.
As such, there’s not much to compare it with, so all we can really say is that it all seems pretty solid and sound, from what we can see.
As you might imagine, it’s a fairly rough and ready machine, so don’t expect Zuffenhausen levels of precision on the panel gaps and shut-lines.
The black paintwork is mainly covered in an all-over ‘Carmageddon’ wrap, which would be very simple to remove and/or replace should you so wish.
There looks to be a little bubbling under the wrap on the removable ‘blades’ and in a couple of other places on the car, but without peeling off the wrap we can’t say for sure whether these indicate the presence of some oxidisation or just a few air bubbles.
The wheels - big and fat at the rear, less so at the front - look good, as do the tyres.
The petrol tank and battery are housed in the rear section of the car, which may be accessed through a roof hatch.
mechanical:
Somewhere under the car’s various spikes, ledges, flaps and scoops the following items are lurking.
454 Chevy Big Block
Turbo 350 Transmission
Edelbrock Performer RPM Camshaft
Edelbrock Performer RPM dual-plane Intake Manifold
Edelbrock 750cfm Carburation
‘Glasspack Zoomies’ Exhaust
Aluminium Radiator from a SRT-8 Jeep
Pontiac 12 Bolt Rear End from a 1979 Grand Am
Custom Driveshaft
Manual Master Cylinder
Front Disk Brakes, Rear Drums
Manual Rack and Pinion Steering
Fuel Cell with Electric Fuel Pump
Electronic Distributor, New lifters, Valve job
Standard Alternator, Water Pump, etc
‘Painless’ Wiring Harness
Centre-mounted Battery with Cut-Off Switch.
5-point Racing Harnesses
Full Gauge Package
They all sound like good things to us, but what do we know?
Incidentally, the ‘blades’ at the front can be easily detached from the car simply by undoing a couple of screws.
We think the throttle may need a little adjustment, as the car clearly wants to get going even when your foot is firmly on the brake.
History:
It doesn’t come with a V5 as it’s not currently registered for road use in the UK.
However, it was previously registered for use in the USA.
We know its history and use since it was first chopped by Iron Customs of Indiana, and there are plenty of photographs and invoices detailing and recording its progress from a 1966 pick-up to the vehicle you see today.
We don’t know anything about its previous life as a Chevy C-10.
Summary:
Looking for all the world like the love child of Robot Wars’ ‘Sir Killalot’ and Dick Dastardly’s ‘Mean Machine’, this snorting, snarling beast of a car is sure to get you noticed in the car park at Waitrose or at your local golf club – provided, of course, that you’ve done the work to make it road legal.
Alternatively, you could keep it in its road-illegal state and trailer it around various fêtes and fairs, where it is guaranteed to delight children, frighten horses and make birds fall from the sky.
A third option would be to strip it down and reveal what’s underneath – a Chevy C-10 that dates from the year that Nancy Sinatra first sang about her boots, Time magazine coined the phrase ‘Swinging London’, and Raquel Welch starred in One Million Years B.C. wearing a bikini that appeared to be fashioned from two, three at most, squirrels.
The choice, dear reader, is entirely yours to make. Either way, you’ll be the proud owner of a unique automotive statement.
We are happy to offer this vehicle for auction with an estimate in the range of £20,000 - £50,000.
Viewing is strongly encouraged, and this lot is located at Bonhams|Cars Online HQ. Viewings are STRICTLY BY APPOINTMENT and we are open weekdays between 10am-12pm or 2pm-4pm. To make a booking, please use the Contact Seller button at the top of the listing. Feel free to ask any questions or try our ‘Frequently Asked Questions’.

Title: 1984 Nissan Skyline R30 GTX
Key Facts: ['BOSS kit to fit a sports steering wheel', '17-inch Gold Alloys (& new tyres)', 'Standard Factory Mild Racing Cam', 'South African Import', 'Purchased from the Datsun & Nissan Heritage Museum', 'NOVA in Place']
interior:
Like stepping back in time, the Skyline’s interior remains in its original condition. The grey material seats do have some wear in keeping with the age of the car, while the rear seat is in good condition with no signs of damage. Both door cards are in reasonably good condition, with just some light staining and a small amount of sagging to the material.
The dashboard is free from splits or cracks, and the instruments are working correctly. The odometer shows a reading of 138,494 kilometres. The switchgear has some light age-related wear, and a couple of the window switch surrounds have split, but all are reported to be working correctly. In place is a double-width - yes, double-width (it’s not very often you see one of those!) - Pioneer radio and cassette player (proper 80's).
The grey carpets are in good condition, with just a small amount of wear on the driver's heel pad, and would benefit from a deep clean. Inside, the boot is in the same condition, and the spare wheel is present with a partially worn tyre.
Background:
The Nissan Skyline 2.8 R30 is a distinctive model from the long-running Skyline series, blending classic 1980s styling with a solid performance package. As part of the R30 generation, which was produced from 1981 to 1985, this particular variant stood out due to its larger displacement engine and refined features. The R30 was available in several configurations, but the 2.8-litre version was powered by the L-Series engine, a naturally aspirated inline-six known for its smooth power delivery and durability. With electronic fuel injection, this engine produced around 145 horsepower, making it a strong performer for its time. Mated to either a five-speed manual or a three-speed automatic transmission, the Skyline 2.8 R30 offered a balance of performance and drivability suitable for both enthusiasts and daily drivers.
Visually, the 1984 Skyline 2.8 R30 retained the sharp, boxy lines that defined the era, an angular design that has aged into a beloved classic. It was available in four-door saloon and two-door coupé body styles, catering to different preferences. Some variants, such as the GT-ES, featured sportier aesthetics with unique badging, alloy wheels, and aerodynamic enhancements. Inside, the cabin was well-equipped for the period, with comfortable seating, a driver-focused cockpit, and, in some models, digital instrumentation, reflecting the high-tech aspirations of the 1980s.
Although not as famous as the turbocharged DR30 variants, which carried the iconic "Red Top" FJ20ET engine, the 2.8 R30 remains a respected model for its reliability, smooth six-cylinder powertrain, and connection to Nissan’s rich motorsport heritage. It was a car that blended performance and practicality, appealing to family buyers and driving enthusiasts alike. Today, well-maintained examples are sought after by collectors and JDM enthusiasts worldwide.
Overview:
Coming to market after its journey to Belfast, where it is currently located, this 1984 Nissan Skyline 2.8 presents a rare opportunity for enthusiasts and collectors alike. Having initially made its way from South Africa in 2023, the vendor reports it spent several years in the Datsun & Nissan Heritage Museum, and there is a letter in the Documents section stating this. The Skyline has remained unregistered since it arrived in Belfast, which means that the winning bidder will have the privilege of becoming the first registered keeper outside of South Africa, adding to the uniqueness of this example.
In preparation for its next custodian, the Skyline has undergone some minor works to ensure it is in excellent condition and ready to be enjoyed. This is a rare chance to acquire an iconic and highly desirable Nissan Skyline 2.8 – an opportunity not to be missed.
exterior:
The Skyline presents well, and for 1984, the bodywork appears to be in good condition, which is obviously helped by South Africa's warm, dry climate. The car has been repainted at some point, as evidenced by small amounts of overspray around the door handles and some of the window trims. The colour plate under the bonnet also suggests that the grey interior and white two-tone exterior are original, remaining period correct.
Starting at the front of the car, the front spoiler and body kit look to be in good condition. The car does have the later-style three-slat grille, and both headlights are free from any chips or cracks; however, the reflectors do look like they have tarnished a little.
Looking down the flanks of the Skyline, there don’t appear to be any dings or dents to mention. The side mouldings look in good condition, and the RS 12-valve SOHC decals are in place. The windows do have some age-related scratches, mainly noticed on the door windows, and the windscreen does have a minor chip that the vendor has addressed, by the use of automotive glass repairers, inserting anti crack spread prevention paste on the passenger side. There is also a piece missing from the nearside door mirror.
At the rear end, featuring what has become iconic amongst the Skyline models, the afterburner lights have a small split in one of the nearside lenses. The trim above the bumper has been refitted with some screws and is slightly distorted, and there is a corner piece missing from the boot lip—all parts which could be sourced.
The original wheels have been replaced with deep-dish six-spoke alloy wheels. These are generally in good condition with just a few minor marks. The vehicle will be supplied with a set of new 17inch gold alloys with new tyres, similar to the original factor alloys.
mechanical:
Fitted with a super smooth straight-six 2.8-litre L-Series engine, the vendor reports that the vehicle benefits from a factory fitted mild racing cam and free flow exhaust system, having the ability to have reached over 170 BHP on a dyno. The Skyline starts on the button and runs with no issues. Several parts have been fitted, which are documented in the paperwork section.
The car is said to drive as it should, and the five-speed gearbox has a smooth change. There is an invoice for upper and lower ball joints along with brake calliper repair kits and new brake pads. The vendor reports the car comes to a stop in a straight line with no juddering through the pedal.
Looking at the underside of the car, this presents well with minimal signs of surface corrosion on the floor and suspension components.
History:
With the car spending several years in a museum and also coming from South Africa, the history is quite sparse. What is present is the registration document from South Africa, along with several invoices for parts purchased and work carried out over the past couple of years. As mentioned earlier, there is also a letter from the Datsun & Nissan Heritage Museum stating that the Skyline was purchased from them in 2022. The vendor tells us the museum is willing to assist with any enquires if needed in respect of the vehicle.
The main point for anyone in the UK buying the car is that the Skyline does have a NOVA certificate, so it is ready to be registered with the DVLA with no issues from HM Revenue & Customs.
Summary:
A desirable JDM classic which, for its age, looks to be in good order with just some minor cosmetic blemishes to the exterior and interior. This makes it the perfect base for anybody wanting to take it to the next level or simply enjoy this Japanese classic as it is.
We estimate this usable example from JDM classic will fetch in the region of £18,000 to £22,000.
Viewing is strongly encouraged, and this particular car is located with the vendor in Belfast, Northern Ireland. To arrange an appointment to inspect this vehicle, please use the ‘Enquire About This Vehicle’ button on the listing. Feel free to ask any questions, or try our ‘Frequently Asked Questions’.

Title: 1937 MG TA
Key Facts: ['Only 4 Previous Keeps', 'UK RHD', 'Photographic record of restoration', 'Features the better XPAG engine', 'An older, documented and fastidious restoration']
interior:
The TA’s cabin looks every inch the equal of the exterior, being finished in a period-feel air force blue hue. The rear-hinged doors open widely to allow access to the full-width bench seat The back of this is formed of a single piece which is stitched into vertical box pleats. This works in conjunction with two sperate seat squabs placed either side of the transmission tunnel to provide commodious seating for two. The door cards on the rear hinged doors are finished in a matching substrate and include a pair of generous map pockets. Carpeting is finished in a darker blue and appears in a fine condition, too. 
The “moustache” shaped dashboard fascia is finished in a wood veneer. A family of British Jaeger gauges populate the panel. The big, convex lenses tachometer sits directly ahead of the driver with a matching speedometer placed ahead of the passenger (what could possibly go wrong?). Auxiliary gauges monitoring oil pressure, amps and water temperature are also present. A “banjo” style four spoke Bluemel’s Brooklands steering wheel is fitted which incorporates a polished boss with MG embossing. 
Charming period details include a folding windscreen, a single windscreen wiper motor operating a cantilever arrangement for both wipers and a portrait orientated, convex lensed wing mirror. The condition of the interior and its faithful originality should be much admired.
Background:
Purists seem to consider the origins of the T type MGs to germinate with the arrival of the M type in 1928. The M type was the first model to be known as a “midget,” a moniker that would continue to be applied to the small MGs right up to the Midget 1500 of 1974. The M type was also considered the first car produced by MG in its own right. Prior to this, MGs were special, rebodied versions of Morris models produced and promoted by Morris’s General Manager, Cecil Kimber. The MG Car Company was registered in its own right only a few weeks before the 1928 London Motor Show at which the M type was premiered.
Over the next eight years the M type was revised and improved to create the C and D types in 1931, the J type in 1932 and ultimately the P type in 1934. The PB that followed was considered to be a much-improved car with its Morris origins now almost completely expunged. Supply problems with the PB’s Wolseley derived overhead camshaft engine led to the car’s demise in 1936.
The MG TA that followed looked similar to the outgoing PB but was fundamentally different in virtually every other way. The TA had a bigger (1292cc versus 939cc) and more powerful (50 hp as opposed to 46 hp) engine. It was a bigger car with a 7” longer wheelbase was longer, making it significantly roomier and more comfortable. The civilising improvements extended to hydraulic brakes and, from August 1936, the addition of a synchromesh on third and fourth gear; a first for the MG midget line. 
The arrival of the TA really marked a transformational watershed in MG’s development. The more “grown up” nature of the new car helped endear the brand to a broader motoring demographic. No longer were its sports cars just the preserve of the dyed in the wool enthusiast, but now offered something to appeal to almost all motorists. The wider appeal of the TA in no way diminished its sporting credentials, however. The standard car was good for over 80mph, and a TA even won its class in the 1939 Australian Grand Prix. Initially priced at the same level as the outgoing PB, a competitive £222 in the UK, the TA represented impressive value. As such it did good business, selling around 3,000 units across its 3-year production window.
Overview:
This fine-looking TA was first registered in Northern Ireland in December 1937 and was thought to have left the Abingdon factory in a grey livery. A second keeper followed who appears to have resided in the Greater London area, certainly during the 1960’s at least. By 2003 the MG had moved on to its third custodian and was now sporting an Old English White livery.
Clearly ripe for a little improvement at this stage, the third keeper embarked on what can only be described as a labour of love to bring the diminutive MG back up to a near factory condition. This fastidious process unfolded over the subsequent seven years, and it is clear that every facet of the TA received the attention it deserved. This third keeper helpfully kept a detailed record, both written and photographic, of every stage of the restoration process which lends some fascinating and valuable provenance to this TA.
In 2010 the fourth previous owner acquired the TA, now in its new and eye-catching Saxe Blue hue. Current owner, Rod, acquired the MG TA in 2013 and has lovingly and carefully curated this remarkable pre-war sports car ever since. This care and attention has extended to the MG enjoying a controlled environment within an air shroud in Rod’s garage.
exterior:
Despite looking very similar to its predecessor, the PB, the TA’s extra 7-inch length did much to balance the look of the car in a positive direction. With such a long and prominent bonnet, the PB’s sharply cut off rear looked a little severe and those extra inches in the TA’s chassis did much to improve the aesthetics. Despite this enlarged footprint the TA remains charmingly diminutive by today’s standards reminding us of how little real estate is actually needed to transport two humans at speeds approaching 80 mph.
This example presents in sophisticated Saxe Blue courtesy of keeper number three’s restoration project in the early 2000’s. The shade suits the car’s well-crafted lines perfectly and seems to add to the TA’s status as a more grown up and useable sports car. The car has clearly been sympathetically used and enjoyed since, then, as the condition of paint and bodywork appears excellent throughout. Judging by the odometer progression in the last 14 years it seems like the MG has covered less than 2,000 or so miles since the completion of its restoration.
The deep blue livery is further complemented by the gleaming brightwork in evidence around the car. This includes radiator shell, headlamp bowls, windscreen surround, wing mirrors and the like. The front aspect of the MG is dominated by those dinner-plate sized headlamps and their mesh stone guards. These sit either side of the tall, vertically slatted radiator. The rear profile of the car is dominated by the body-coloured, externally mounted petrol tank and accompanying spare wire wheel and unused tyre. 
The black, fabric hood appears tightly fitting and in excellent condition. The rear acetate windows are clear and free from obscuring folds or crack. Matching side screens affix to the door tops to complete the full complement of weather protection precautions. A full-length tonneau is also provided.
The TA rides on a set of cross spoked wire wheels that are finished in a silver-grey hue. Their condition appears excellent throughout and are dressed in a set of chromed MG twin-eared spinners A set of new looking, period-appropriate radial tyres are fitted.
mechanical:
Accompanying documentation and this car’s registered engine number (rather than the original one stamped into the engine bay data plate) reveals that this TA at some point acquired an engine from the later MG TB. This should be considered as a very good thing. The TA’s MPJG engine from the Wolseley Ten was considered a bit of a weak link and was always viewed as a developmental cul de sac by MG. The XPAG 1250cc unit fitted here, however, would go on to power a range of MG cars for the next 15 years or so. Proving a much more tuneable unit, the factory specification claimed a 54bhp output at 5,200 rpm.
We know from the thorough restoration records that some significant engine work was undertaken in 2004 and further supported by the photographic record. This included the fitment of new pistons, main bearings and big ends, a re-core and re-face of the block and regrind of the crank shaft. Unleaded valve seats were also fitted at this stage. This work is thought to have been undertaken just a few thousand miles ago.
The under-bonnet presentation of the TA is excellent, of course. Lifting the panels of the gull-winged bonnet reveals a deeply polished cam cover atop a red painted block. There are numerous areas of charming detail in here, too. These include the brass data plates, the spare spark plug receptacle, a pair of wooden lidded and fully stocked tool chests. The underside of the car looks pleasingly fresh and clean and in keeping with a full restoration just a few thousand miles ago.
History:
There is plenty to get your teeth into here. The current V5 registration document is present. The MG’s Historic Vehicle status designates it as MoT exempt and zero rated for vehicle excise duty in the UK. A certified copy of the original “logbook” is also on hand. 
The remainder of the archive includes the highlights of the carefully and diligently logged restoration covering the period between 2004 and 2010. Not only is there a very comprehensive photographic record (also helpfully date stamped) but also supporting documentation accounting for parts acquired and work undertaken across 6 years. Other later invoices are also included and make for interesting reading.
Summary:
The MG TA was a foretaste of what was to come with the T-type MG’s that would ultimately prevail well into the 1950’s. An origin of the species car that moved MG from a niche enthusiasts’ marque ultimately into one with a broader and worldwide appeal. Later iterations of the TA would go on to emphatically conquer the critical North American market and cement MG’s place as possibly the best known of sports car makers. And it all started here.
This example represents an exciting ownership prospect without doubt. It has clearly been beautifully and lovingly restored over six years and subsequently diligent kept and cared for. It is hard to find fault with it. The main weakness of the TA, it’s stop-gap engine, has been replaced with the much more admired XPAG unit from the TB. Surely this combination is a winning one and one that may prove hard to better.  
We are happy to offer this car for auction with an estimate in the range of £20,000 - £30,000.
Viewing is always encouraged, and this particular car is located with the vendor in Inverurie, Aberdeenshire. To arrange an appointment to view this vehicle please use the Contact Seller button at the top of the listing. Feel free to ask any questions or make observations in the comments section below, or try our ‘Frequently Asked Questions’.

Title: 1978 Alfa Romeo Spider 2000 S2
Key Facts: ['Desirable S2 Model', 'Lots Of Recent Mechanical Works', 'Driven 2 Hours To Our HQ', 'UK Specified and Supplied RHD']
interior:
The S2 Spider’s cabin is as stylish as it is admirably analogue and tantalisingly tactile. The seats are finished in burgundy Alfatex. These are finished in vertical, padded box pleats for additional support and comfort. The S2 even features some vestigial rear seats but they are decidedly on the... snug... side, best suited to luggage or small dogs. The condition of the upholstery is generally good, and the burgundy shade works well with the blue exterior livery. There are some small splits noted to the seat backs. The door cards are finished with numerous chrome trim pieces atop matching burgundy, pleated Alfatex. There are a few marks and scuffs reported to these.
The S2 features an oversized pair of Jaeger Italia, white on black main gauges which each enjoy their own deeply hooded binnacle. These sit directly behind a deeply dished, three spoke Alfa Romeo alloy steering wheel with a varnished wooden rim. The centre console is home to a trio of driver facing ancillary Jaeger gauges. These sit above a period faithful Sharp ANSS radio cassette player. The Alfa Romeo embossed rubber mats, bottom hinged clutch and brake pedal, and signature high mounted gear lever round off this most Alfa of cabins perfectly.
The well sized boot is trimmed with an original, fitted vinyl mat. Lifting this reveals the spare wheel and tyres together with an original looking pillar jack.
Background:
Automotive impresario Max Hoffman was a divisive, if hugely influential figure. Industry giant, Bob Lutz who served as the leader of all “top three” US automakers, listed Hoffman as one of the “shadiest people he ever worked with” in 2019. Lutz claimed that much of Hoffman’s success and influence was “built on bribery and extortion.” Whatever the truth Hoffman was instrumental in various car manufacturers producing some of their most iconic models of the 1950’s and 1960’s. Think Mercedes-Benz 300SL Gullwing, Porsche 356 Speedster and BMW 507 Roadster – in other words, some serious metal!
Even before the public launch of the Alfa Romeo Sprint Coupe based on the 101 Series Giulietta, the company presented the vehicle to Max Hoffman for his comment. Hoffman was lukewarm about the car and pressed Alfa Rome to construct an open, two-seated roadster version which he felt would be significantly more marketable. He even sweetened the suggestion with a promise to take the first 600 cars built. In no time at all, a prototype was developed and in the following year, the gorgeous Giulietta Spider was presented at the International Motor Show in New York City.
The Giulietta Spider was a great success and when the 105 Series Giulia was launched in 1962 a Giulia Spider Veloce followed on in 1963. With the Spider model really capturing the zeitgeist of the 1960’s the model would receive another update in 1966. This followed a veritable blizzard of Pininfarina design studies and concept cars. The Alfa Romeo Spider 1600 was launched at the Geneva Motor Show of 1966.
Max Hoffman had one more card to play in terms of the Spider, however. In 1967 Max Hoffman’s nephew, Dustin, was cast as the lead in Mike Nichols’s “The Graduate.” When “Uncle Max” learned of this he offered the production the use of three Spider 1600’s in one of the most inspired and successful examples of early product placement. Seemingly Nichols didn’t sell out entirely to Max Hoffman, however. When Anne Bancroft’s Mrs Robinson asks Dustin’s Ben Braddock of his red Alfa “what sort of car is this?” he simply replies, “I don’t know.” An opportunity missed, perhaps, but it didn’t seem to matter.
Overview:
Our example is a desirable Series 2 Spider. For some the Series 1’s sharp "osso di seppia" (Italian for cuttlebone) rear end was a jarring facet of the otherwise sleek and attractive design. The Series 2 model replaced this with a more contemporary Kamm tail or “coda tronca”, improving the cars universal appeal as well as significantly increasing boot capacity. For the Series 2 an enlarged 2-litre version of the legendary “Nord” twin-cam engine was introduced for the first time. It is that esteemed two-litre version that can be found here.
This bright looking example is notable for being a UK specified and supplied right hand drive model and first registered in March 1978. Between 1978 and 2000 this Spider passed through the hands of four registered keepers. In intervening 25 years, this bright blue Alfa Romeo has been in the stewardship of just two further keepers. Our current owner, acquired the Spider in 2017 and has added around 5,000 miles under his stewardship. Today the Jaeger Italia odometer stands at a shade over 81,000 miles.
exterior:
The world of Alfa Romeo paint colours is an mysterious, twisted world devoid of system or clarity, so it seems. The bright blue shade of this fine example is sometime referred to a “Dutch Blue,” “French Blue,” “Le Mans Blue” or “Mid-Blue.” What we can report with absolute certainty is that it is... indeed blue.
What’s more it suits the sculpted shape of the S2 Spider rather well and seems to exude a pleasing overall shine. That said a number of imperfections were noted upon close inspection.
These include some areas of overspray in places, hinting at a more contemporary respray. Other minor issues include paint swirls and scratches to most panels, some stone chips on the bonnet and leading edge of the doors. Please study our photographic package at your leisure or arrange a viewing to assess the Spider’s overall condition. A moderate tally of chromed brightwork is present, mainly embellishing the slimline bumpers, windscreen surround and exhaust tail pipe.
The vibrant paintwork is complemented perfectly by the blue, fabric hood. This fits taughtly, appears free from major stains or blemished and features a clear and crack-free rear window. A small tear in the foam and fabric near the passenger door is noted and is photographed for your review. The 14-hole steel wheels are 14-inch items and finished in silver. The original, period chromed finishing centre caps are fitted and feature the iconic Alfa Romeo shield in black. The wheels are in a good overall condition with some minor bubbling and surface corrosion in evidence. A matching set of 165 configuration Hankook tyres are fitted.
mechanical:
Alfa Romeo’s hugely admired Twin Cam engine is an all-alloy inline-four unit, produced between 1954 and 1994. Known to Italians as the "bialbero" ("twin-shaft"), this unit is also known as the "Nord" (North) engine in reference to its being originally built in Portello, Milan in the North of Italy. This fabled unit was an original design by the legendary Giuseppe Busso. In this application the Nord engine was rated at around 130bhp and, in this case, is fitted with a pair of 40 DCOE Weber carburettors. This Spider features a five speed manual gearbox in transaxle guise.
Lifting the bonnet reveals the Nord engine to be a fine looking unit by today’s heavily fared in standards. The Alfa Romeo debossed rocker covers catch the eye first. The clutch servo, brake servo and quality Bosch battery are all clearly recently fitted. The inner panels appear to be in good shape as do the various ancillaries and electrical components. A minor oil leak was noted during our photo shoot. The underside of the Spider looks to be well protected by underseal with just the peripheries of the body panels looking a little corroded in places. The suspension components look well preserved but our consignment team note that the Spider pulls to the right a little.
History:
There’s an interesting and instructive archive of paperwork included with the Spider. This includes the current V5 Registration Document in the name of the current owner. This classifies the Alfa Romeo as an Historic Vehicle and, hence, MoT exempt and zero rated for vehicle excise duty. Numerous earlier MoTs are present helping to support the Spider’s mileage progression to date.
The bulk of the remainder of the paperwork consists of plenty of invoices from throughout the car’s history. In the current ownership the Alfa Romeo has consistently been maintained by Alfa specialists Bianco Auto Developments in Surrey. Over £9,000 has been spent since 2017 covering a range of routine and one off maintenance and repair activities. Plenty of earlier invoices are also on hand as is a Spider specific workshop manual.
Summary:
The Alfa Romeo Spider seemed to really hits its stride in Series 2 guise and has remained enduringly popular since. Although the S2 two-litre iteration of the Spider is by far the most numerously produced, the numbers were still quite modest with just 3,868 built in 1978. With the passing years having taken a figurative wrecking ball to these numbers, good examples of the S2 are becoming increasingly scarce.
This example appears admirably original and benefits from a less common and appealing colourway. With an eminently sensible mileage, thought to be original, and a moderate number of former keepers this Spider boasts a very solid provenance indeed. Much has been spent keeping this Spider in such a useable condition, too. With the supply of honest UK cars become increasingly constrained this Spider should represent not only a sound investment but a highly enjoyable one, too.
We are happy to offer this car for auction with an estimate in the range of £15,000 - £20,000.
Viewing is strongly encouraged, and this lot is located at Bonhams|Cars Online HQ. Viewings are STRICTLY BY APPOINTMENT and we are open weekdays between 10am - 12pm or 2pm - 4pm. To make a booking, please use the ‘Enquire About This Vehicle’ button on the listing. Feel free to ask any questions, or try our ‘Frequently Asked Questions’.

Title: 1978 Datsun 260Z
Key Facts: ['Offered from long-term ownership', 'Offered with original books and manuals', 'Well preserved and increasingly desirable']
interior:
The interior continues the authenticity theme with the seats still being covered by the original fabric and vinyl.

Which would be a story all by itself even if they were frayed and full of holes; that they’re still plump and firm and free of any obvious damage, or even signs of wear, is remarkable.

The rear seats, individual and looking supremely snug and comfortable, are in an even better shape and we think it would be a safe bet that they haven’t seen much use over the years; just take a look at the sticker on the back of the passenger seat, for example.

The dashboard holds the factory fitted Hitachi radio, and the instruments and controls are still bright and legible, including the wonderfully labelled blue REAR DEFOGGER.

The black carpets are also still in great shape, and the door cards have survived the passage of almost half a century very well. Wonderfully, the electrically operated front windows are courtesy of ‘Servoglide’.

Which reminds us that the seller assures us that everything works as it should.

More luxury comes via some very of-the-period fake wood trim, and the huge Webasto-style sunroof and inner headlining are both in an excellent condition.

The steering wheel does show a little more wear but even that is more a case of some of the grain pattern having been rubbed off rather than anything more serious – and we really do mean “some of” because it, like everything else in the cockpit, is very good indeed.

As for the boot, the carpet in there is sun-faded and worn but it is still more than acceptable, especially if you value originality above all else.

Which means that problems are minor: the Perspex visor on the sunroof has a crack in it and a short section of the material covering the offside door card has come adrift on one edge.
Background:
The replacement for the beloved 240Z, the 260Z was only in production between 1974 and 1978. With a bigger, 2,565cc engine courtesy of a longer stroke, the 260Z boasted 162bhp, which is usefully more than the outgoing car’s 151bhp. Torque was up too, and the Datsun could be had with a four-speed or five-speed manual gearbox, or a three-speed automatic.

The suspension was pretty much carried over from the 240Z, as were the brakes. The chassis was a bit stiffer but the changes were gentle evolution rather than anything bolder but that was understandable; the 240Z was widely lauded for its handling and why bother fixing it if it ain’t broke?

Performance is strong rather than vivid with the benchmark 60mph arriving after eight seconds dead on its way to a top speed of 127mph. Mind you, that’s better than two miles per minute, which is enough really, isn’t it?

It also feels faster than the car it replaced, with Motorsport writing at the time “the 260Z feels much more flexible and much quicker than the old 240” before summing it up: “This distinctive beast from the other side of the world is a true sports car in that it is fast, handles well, requires skill to drive it very quickly but is tremendous fun while doing so. On the other hand it is also a true GT car, for two, for it is capacious, comfortable, has a lazy, 120 m.p.h. cruising gait yet has a sensible fuel range. No wonder it sells so well.”

A 2+2, with a 300mm longer wheelbase, widened the Datsun’s appeal still further. A notched roofline to give a bit more rear headroom is the easiest way to spot one, and the transmission tunnel gained proper carpet rather than the quilted vinyl of the two-seater.

Time has been kind to the 240/260Z, and while rust is the biggest issue you’ll face the mechanicals are robust and strong, with 400,000 miles easily possible on the original engine if it’s maintained properly.
Overview:
Still finished in its original yellow and boasting a black vinyl roof, ‘BTW 62T’ is a very of-the-seventies Datsun 260Z 2+2 that had just one owner between 1980 and the seller buying it in May 2024.

He used to work for Datsun back in the day, and seeing the authenticity of this UK-supplied, manual example left him with no option but to bid – and we can absolutely see the appeal, with bodywork even our hard-nosed assessor described as “great”.

It’s got plenty of original interior fixtures and fittings too, is utterly solid, and runs like a dream all of which means we expect this legendary sportscar to attract an awful lot of interest.
exterior:
The yellow paintwork is wonderful, isn’t it? We suspect, in fact we’re sure, it’s had work over the years but the fact it still wears its factory hue as proudly as it does is a wonderful thing.

As is the black vinyl roof, another period feature we’re always pleased to see alongside period essentials like a boot spoiler, twin exhaust tailpipes, a deep front air dam, and some chunky four-spoke OE Nissan alloy wheels.

The latter are free of scrapes, scuffs, and other parking damage and are also fitted with a full set of 175/80R14 Hankook Kinergy Eco tyres.

We will never get tired of telling you that experience shows that matching high-quality tyres are an infallible sign of a caring and mechanically sympathetic owner who is prepared to spend the appropriate amount in maintaining their car properly.

As for the condition of the rest of the coachwork, the panels still fit very well. With good shutlines and no ripples along the flanks, there’s also a remarkable lack of the sort of dinks and dents you’d expect a car of this age to have collected along the way.

Being a car of the seventies there’s a smattering of chromework too of course, and this is in good shape and largely free of pitting and rust. It’s also great to see that the bumpers run nice and straight.

The glass is good too, and we can see the windows have been etched with the car’s registration number.

The badges are a little faded but carry an authentic patina, and the lamp lenses are bright and free of damage.

Which brings us onto the subject of issues you might like to get ahead of.

You’ll be pleased to hear there really aren’t many other than some bubbling around the boot aperture.
mechanical:
The seller took the 260Z out of winter hibernation a couple of weeks ago and treated it to fresh fuel plus a new fuel filter and pump. As you can see, the 2.6-litre engine starts and runs very well: as the seller says, that legendary Japanese engineering still shines through, even now.

The engine bay is as original as everything else; true, there is scope for improvement if detailing is your thing or you plan to show it, but we imagine most folk would be more than happy to leave it as it is, especially given nobody has tried to prettify it over the years with inappropriate ‘upgrades’ like silicone hoses and anodized fittings.

As for the underside, we don’t think describing it as exceptional is too strong because it looks to be very well preserved thanks to a winning combination of diligent curation and factory underseal.

And it’s not just us that thinks this: while the MoT record might be patchy, there’s never been any mention of underbody corrosion or structural rot, which would seem to confirm our impressions.

It will almost certainly need some work before it will pass an MoT, as it failed in April 2022 on the following:

• Headlamp not working on dipped beam (4.1.1 (a) (ii))
• Nearside Front Position lamp not working (4.2.1 (a) (ii))
• Offside Front Position lamp not working (4.2.1 (a) (ii))
• Exhaust emissions carbon monoxide content excessive (8.2.1.2 (b))
• Service brake efficiency below requirements (1.2.2 (a) (i))

It was also given an advisory for: Exhaust emits black smoke during acceleration (8.2.1.2 (g))
History:
The Datsun doesn’t have a current MoT certificate, and while it is exempt by virtue of its age, we would strongly encourage the new owner to have it MoT’d at the earliest opportunity. The cost of an MoT is a small investment when offset against the purchase and upkeep of any classic vehicle, and it gives an independent, third-party assessment of the car’s condition, which not only provides reassurance to the owner (and any subsequent purchasers) but might also be invaluable in the event of a bump when negotiating with the police and any interested insurance companies…

It's been a while since it’s had a ticket but the 57,461 miles that’s currently showing on its odometer ties in with the 57,240 miles recorded by the Man from the Ministry when it last passed in 2007.

The recent Vehicle History Check is clear, and the history file includes the original stamped service history booklet, the owner’s handbook, and the rest of the bumf in the wallet most people would have thrown out, which means that even the paperwork has charm.
Summary:
Cars like this, that haven’t been messed around with and are largely original, are rarer than you imagine – and Japanese cars from the seventies that have survived as well as this are even rarer.
And this is no ordinary Japanese car; it’s an icon, a sporting legend, and while the profile of the 2+2 coupé might lack a little of the purity of the two-seater original, that is reflected in the price.
Which we expect to settle between £18,000 and £24,000, which feels like remarkable value for such an original and solid example that could continue to fulfill the role of thrilling sportscar.
And if you wanted to further improve it and show it as an example of what European car manufacturers feared all those years ago, even that would be within easy reach of the average DIYer.
Viewing is strongly encouraged, and this particular car is located with the vendor in Huntingdon, Cambridgeshire. To arrange an appointment to inspect this vehicle, please use the ‘Enquire About This Vehicle’ button on the listing. Feel free to ask any questions, or try our ‘Frequently Asked Questions’.

Title: 1972 Volkswagen T2 Campervan
Key Facts: ['High Quality Restoration by Morecambe & Wize Ltd', 'Ready For Summer', 'Californian Import']
interior:
The cabin was completely rebuilt in 2017 too, and the new furniture includes a full-width rock ‘n’ roll bed with space for another two to sleep under the pop-up roof above. 

The rock ‘n’ roll bed provides seating for three and there’s an additional buddy seat opposite with storage space underneath. This means you can sit around the stowaway table that cleverly tucks away in the rear roof space when it’s not being used.

All the seating was repaired as necessary in 2017 before being recovered in Champagne vinyl material. This included the cushions for the bed and the front seats. Interestingly, the front and buddy seats are embossed with the ‘MW’ logo, which is a lovely touch and one that gives us even more confidence in the quality of the rest of the work.

The front seats have seatbelts fitted, and the spares that come with the ‘van include another two that could be fitted in the rear.

Curtains are fitted throughout, and there is enough spare new material to make another set. Linen and blankets are also included.

The flooring is in an excellent condition with only a few minor marks.

New cabinets were also fitted by M&W, along with a new fridge/freezer, sink, and two-ring gas hob.

Electrickery includes a face-off Sony headunit and speakers, USB charging points, and a leisure battery with a hook-up point for connecting to the mains. EHU cables are included.

There’s a remote-controlled immobiliser too, and the instructions for using this are in the history file.

The seller is full of praise for the cleverness of the campervan’s interior; she says they never felt cramped, and when they pitched up at a campsite her job was to raise the roof while her husband plugged them in to shore power “and within five minutes we were drinking tea!” she laughed.

Mind you, by the time M&W built this one they had got eight years of experience under their belt, so the fact they’d got the design and build quality nailed isn’t a surprise.

The dashboard is the original and as for cosmetic flaws, there are a couple of marks to the door cards, the steering wheel is a little more patinated than everything else, and there is overspray on the pedals.

So, again, trivial stuff.
Background:
The Volkswagen Type 2 Transporter van’s forward control layout endowed it with huge versatility, and it was configured in a bewildering number of variants, from a hard-core panel van that lacked both rear seats and side windows through to the (reasonably) luxurious Samba Deluxe with its two-tone paint finish, full-length headlining and eight passenger seats.

What they all have in common is the Beetle’s - and later the Porsche 914’s - iconic flat-four, rear-mounted air-cooled engine and while the Type 2 might have started life modestly it gained both capacity and power over the years, ending its life in Germany with a 1600cc, 47bhp engine and in America with a two-litre, 65bhp unit.

It is perhaps best known for the ubiquitous campervan, which started life as a home brewed concoction used for travel to places as exotic as Iran and Afghanistan.

Now thoroughly modernised, like this example, they tend to be fitted with a double bed, a sink and a cooker unit plus, perhaps, a rising roof for more headroom and additional sleeping space.

A whole new generation are discovering the delights of a life that includes a T2 camper in it; whether being used as a day van that provides hot drinks and a shelter for hard-core surfers or a long-term home for overlanding and exploration, few things in life are as faithful and reliable as a Type 2 Transporter.

By the time production ended almost 1.5 million Transporters of various hues and roles had rolled off European production lines - and it’s fair to say that a significant percentage of them are still trundling along thanks to a fanatical following and an almost unparalleled spares and support network.

Famously robust, reliable, and hugely popular, the Type 2 remained in production in Brazil until increasingly stringent regulations finally killed it off in 2013.
Overview:
Finished in Sunflower Yellow and Champagne – has any colour combination ever better summed up vanlife – this 1972 Volkswagen Type 2 Transporter campervan came to these shores from the sunny climes of California in 2017.

‘HHR 760K’, who is known within her family as Sophia, was built and completely restored in the same year by VW campervan specialists Morecambe and Wize. The work was comprehensive, comprising a bare metal respray before being refitted with many new and reconditioned components, including the rebuilt original 1600cc air-cooled engine.

The seller and her husband chose to commission Sophia from this particular company after hiring a camper van called Ernie, that had been restored by M&W, as a surprise weekend away – and they went from just one trip to buying Sophia within a month, which speaks volumes as to the quality of their work.

They found dealing with Morecambe and Wize a delight too, and the past years with her in their lives have been wonderful: “She was our pride and joy. Everywhere we went people loved her. She's been totally reliable; she's never broken down”.

Freshly serviced and fitted with a new battery at the very end of 2024, only a change in circumstances is forcing the sale of this beloved campervan.
exterior:
The Transporter was stripped down to a bare shell in 2017 as the first stage in its restoration. The bodyshell was then soda-blasted before being etch primed and then painted in Sunflower Yellow, a wonderful shade that is straight out of the VW catalogue.

All of the metalwork was covered, so the engine bay and interior are finished to the same high standard as the exterior.

The wheels and bumpers were then colour-coded in Lotus White to complement the coachwork, as was the pop-up roof. The latter also received new fabric sides and new seals when it was reinstalled, with the doors and windows also being refitted with new rubber seals.

The front of the ‘van was refreshed in December 2024, and the overall condition is very good indeed with excellent shutlines and an attractive gloss to the paintwork.

But then it should look good given how well she’s been looked after. How well? We hear you ask. Well, let’s put it this way; her husband went to the trouble and expense of raising their garage roof to provide Sophia with somewhere dry to live: “She’s very much a part of the family.”

The steel wheels are finished with a set of chromed hubcaps, and the T2 sits on 185R14 tyres, with one being an Event Road 2005, and the other three being Kormoran Vanpro. The spare tyre, which lives on the nearside rear inside the cabin, is a brand new Event that still has the label on it.

The pop-up roof rises and falls as it should, and the fabric sides look very smart. The fabric is also fitted with mesh inserts to provide a draft of air while still keeping the bugs out.

There’s a recess up top too, plus lash-down points, so it could be used to carry light luggage.

The lamp lenses, window glazing, and badges are all good, the numberplates are a pair of smart pressed aluminium plates, and a natty aerial sits on the offside front.

As for flaws, there is a dink on the offside of the rear bumper, minor surface corrosion and pitting to front headlight covers and the wiper arms, an area of bubbling beneath the offside rear door, and a small chip to the offside rear panel just below the window.

There is excess adhesive on rubber trim on the doorsteps, sticker residue on the rear panels, evidence of overspray on some door rubbers, and very light staining to the paint near the fuel cap.

Nothing much to worry about then, and you could sort most of that with a weekends work and minimal investment other than elbow grease.
mechanical:
As you can see, the original engine, which was rebuilt in 2017 as part of the restoration, starts and runs very well indeed.

The only mechanical problem we are aware of is the engine cover, which is stiff and would benefit from adjustment, lubrication and/or a new catch.

It should also be kept on a battery trickle charger to prevent discharge.

The engine bay is nicely presented, and bears witness to that recent expenditure.

As for the underside, it’s as clean and strong as you’d expect to see on a recently restored vehicle that’s spent much of its life in the sunny Californian climate – and been so thoroughly pampered here in the UK.
History:
The VW’s MoT certificate expired in October 2024, which means it doesn’t have a current MoT certificate. Yes, it is exempt by virtue of its age, but we would nonetheless encourage the new owner to have it MoT’d at the earliest opportunity.

The recent Vehicle History Check is clear bar the marker for being an imported vehicle, and the VW comes with two sets of keys and two remote
controls for the immobiliser.

The invoices for the work in 2017 by Morecambe and Wize are on file, as is the invoice for the comprehensive service and new battery it received in December 2024.
Summary:
With a guide price of between £22,000 and £27,000, this Volkswagen Type 2 campervan offers the enthusiast an awful lot of possibilities: it could be used for weekends and holidays away, both here and abroad; it could be used to encompass the whole #vanlife lifestyle, giving you a place to live and work from; or it could be used as a haven to support your hobbies.

Heck, it could even be used as a promotional/hospitality vehicle for your business, with all the tax breaks that could involve.

Regardless of what you use it for, this is a delightfully presented, strong, and reliable way to ease yourself into the VW campervan scene – and given it wove its magic on the seller back in 2017, we’re confident it’ll do the same for you and your family in 2025!
Viewing is strongly encouraged, and this lot is located at Bonhams|Cars Online HQ. Viewings are STRICTLY BY APPOINTMENT and we are open weekdays between 10am - 12pm or 2pm - 4pm. To make a booking, please use the ‘Enquire About This Vehicle’ button on the listing. Feel free to ask any questions, or try our ‘Frequently Asked Questions’.

Title: 2001 Jaguar XKR
Key Facts: ['£3,000 Spent On Sale Preparation', 'Supercharged Quad-Cam V8', 'MoT Till January 2026', 'Large Service & History File', '370 BHP', '5 Speed Automatic', 'Cherished Plate Included']
interior:
Open the door and step inside to a luxurious, leather-clad interior. The heated black leather seats are in good condition, with just a tiny amount of age-related cracking on the front seats, mainly noted on the driver’s seat, as expected. The rear seat is excellent and doesn’t appear to have seen a tremendous amount of use over its 24-year existence. Both door panels are in good condition and free from scuffs or damage.
The dashboard is in good condition and features a walnut trim. The fascia has some minor cracks in the lacquered finish, which is quite common as these cars age. The instruments are reported to be working correctly, and the odometer shows a reading of 91,347 miles, with no warning lights present when the car is running. All of the switchgear is said to be functioning correctly, and there are no real signs of wear on any of the buttons. The factory head unit is in place, featuring satellite navigation, which the owner reports to be working correctly.
A common issue in these cars is sagging headlining, but not with this one! The headlining has been replaced to rectify this well-known problem. The carpets throughout the cabin show little sign of excessive use, and the same can be said for the inside of the boot, which is clean and tidy and holds the original spare wheel.
Background:
Introduced in 1996 as Jaguar’s answer to the ageing XJS, the XK8’s graceful and restrained lines were penned by chief stylist Geoff Lawson and were available as either a three-door hatchback coupé or a two-door convertible, with both models presented in a 2+2 format.
Under the clamshell bonnet sat a 4.0-litre, 32-valve V8 engine, codenamed the AJ-V8. This was all mightily impressive as it sat, but for real performance enthusiasts, the XK8 never quite hit the mark.
Thankfully, their prayers were answered in 1998 when the ‘big brother’ XKR was introduced. Now, performance Jaguar enthusiasts had something to get excited about. The same 4.0-litre AJ-V8 engine was used up front, but a 2.0-litre Eaton supercharger was bolted on, increasing the power output to an impressive 370bhp, all of which was sent through the sizeable rear wheels. The XKR has a top speed of 155mph and can shift from 0 to 60mph in 5.2 seconds.
Whilst the power output was a marked change, visual differences between the ‘8’ and the ‘R’ were minimal, being limited to a mesh grille, rear spoiler, and a louvred bonnet to improve airflow.
Overview:
This meticulously maintained 2001 Jaguar XKR is now available on the market, having recently undergone over £3,000 worth of work to address various minor issues and ensure it is in excellent condition for its next custodian. With these improvements, the XKR is now in peak mechanical and cosmetic health, ready to be enjoyed by its next owner.
Boasting a high level of specification, this well-appointed Jaguar XKR features satellite navigation, luxurious leather upholstery, and elegant walnut trim, all of which contribute to its refined and timeless appeal. Furthermore, the vehicle is accompanied by an excellent service history, which the vendor reports to be fully comprehensive, reflecting the care and attention it has received over the years.
exterior:
The 2001 Jaguar XKR’s distinctively elegant yet aggressive styling sets it apart as a true British grand tourer. As the high-performance version of the XK8, the XKR builds upon the sleek and curvaceous design of its predecessor while adding sportier and more assertive visual cues.
From the front, the car is in good order. There are a couple of age-related stone chips, as you would expect to see, which are in keeping with the mileage. The bonnet aligns well with the wing rails and holds two vents, hinting at the power beneath. The headlights have a small amount of condensation, but this could possibly be dried out and resealed.
Looking at the XKR’s side profile, the doors align evenly with equal gaps. The door mouldings appear straight; there is a small amount of corrosion on the window trims, but the windows are in good order with no noticeable scratches.
At the rear, both lights are in good condition, with no splits or cracks in the lenses. The chrome boot handle has a bright finish. The bumper section has parking sensors fitted and is free of scuffs or marks.
The wheels have been upgraded to ten-spoke deep-dish split rims with a polished finish. They are in excellent condition, with just the odd minor mark, and all four tyres have an excellent amount of tread remaining.
mechanical:
Fitted with the fantastic 4.0-litre V8, Jaguar enhanced this powerplant by attaching an Eaton supercharger, boosting performance figures to approximately 370bhp and 387lb-ft of torque. It’s no slouch, and it sounds fantastic.
The car fires up without hesitation and runs with no faults reported. It has recently had all the belts and tensioners replaced, along with other necessary work, ensuring it runs correctly. The gearbox shifts smoothly, and as you can imagine, with a 4.0-litre supercharged V8 under the bonnet, it pulls through the gears exceptionally well.
On the road, no knocks or bangs have been reported to come from any corner of the car, and the rear subframe has recently been replaced. The car comes to a stop in a straight line with no juddering through the brake pedal.
Generally, the underside appears to be in good order. Some repair work and repainting have been carried out on the sills, but the rest of the floor area looks to be in good condition, along with the exhaust, which has only minor surface corrosion.
History:
With 91,347 miles on the clock, this Jaguar XKR comes with an excellent service history. As mentioned earlier, the belts and tensioners were recently replaced, along with the rear subframe and other necessary work, totalling £3,107.68. The vendor feels this was worth it, as it addressed all the issues noted on previous MoT tests.
A recent MoT was carried out on 27th January 2025, passing with no advisories, giving the next custodian peace of mind.
Summary:
Fast becoming a modern classic, the Jaguar XKR is a fantastic choice for those who appreciate grand tourers with a big V8 under the bonnet. Not just any V8, but a supercharged V8, backed up with an excellent service history—what’s not to love about this big cat?
Perfect for cruising along the coast or country roads, yet equally enjoyable around town, where you can fully appreciate the low, rumbling tones of a supercharged V8 while sitting in the luxurious cockpit of the XKR.
We estimate this well-presented modern British classic will fetch in the region of £7,000 - £9,000.
Viewing is strongly encouraged, and this particular car is located with the vendor in Sonning Common, Berkshire. To arrange an appointment to inspect this vehicle, please use the ‘Enquire About This Vehicle’ button on the listing. Feel free to ask any questions, or try our ‘Frequently Asked Questions’.

Title: 2013 Jaguar XKR
Key Facts: ['Supercharged V8', '20” Alloy Wheels', 'Keyless Entry and Start', 'Dynamic “R” Styling', 'Parking Sensors', 'Extended Leather']
interior:
Boasting the extended Ivory leather trim with the Autolux console, ‘R’ Racing leather finish, contrast stitching, and ‘Pistol Grip’ aluminium pack, the interior of this XKR balances luxury and sportiness as well as any model we’ve ever seen.
It’s survived well too, shrugging off 13 years and 66,000 miles more lightly than most, but then that’s Japanese curation for you.
As well as being luxurious and sporting, the toys it boasts are impressive and include heated and cooled front seats with 16-way electric adjustment, sports rear seats, a heated steering wheel, and an Ebony suede headlining.
The premium sound system includes Bluetooth connectivity, Apple CarPlay and Android Auto, a multi-slot CD player, eight high-performance Bowers &
Wilkins speakers with chrome bezels, and an inbuilt navigation system that’s been updated to feature UK maps.
The radio can obviously access the full spectrum of British stations, and the changes to bring it to the same specification as a British car includes a MPH speedometer.
Technology includes keyless entry and start, a rear-view camera, and auto-dimming rearview mirror in addition to the usual suspects like full climate control, and electric mirrors and windows.
The boot is very clean and home to the space-saver spare wheel, tool kit, and hazard warning triangle.
As for flaws, our man reports that “the overall interior condition is very good. Some of the window switches and the central dash buttons have started to go sticky and have faded but the air-conditioning blows cold, and all the interior electrics appear to work.”
The ’gummy button’ problem has been an issue with many manufacturers, and the Internet is awash with suggestions on how to fix it.
Background:
Launched in 2006, the second-generation XK, code-named ‘X150’, maintained the earlier car’s tradition of being more of a grand tourer than an out-and-out sportscar. Sharing its bonded and rivetted aluminium monocoque chassis with the XJ saloon, its all-aluminium construction saved around 100kgs in weight while also consigning the rust that plagued the previous generation to the history books.
Available as both a 2+2 coupé and a convertible, the post-2009 cars, of which this is one, were given a mild facelift in addition to new 5.0-litre V8 engines.
The slowest model has a naturally aspirated V8, albeit one that offers its driver 380bhp and 380lb/ft of torque, enough for a top speed of 155mph after passing 60mph in five and a half seconds.
The XKR you see here is fitted with a monstrous supercharged V8 under the bonnet. With 503bhp and 461lb/ft of torque, it might share the same artificially limited top speed of 155mph but it knocks around a second off the normally aspirated car’s 0-60mph time.
Jaguar had built almost 27,000 cars by the time production ended in 2016, which means there are plenty out there to choose from. This means there is no need to pick a dodgy one, and so we are delighted to be able to introduce you to this absolute peach of an example of the Jaguar XKR.
Overview:
If you’ve ever fancied a Jaguar XKR but have been put off by the perils of indifferent maintenance amplified by the damage a dozen British winters can wreak, then we’ve got just the car for you.
Finished in Rhodium Silver, the cabin is trimmed in Ivory leather and the fabulously named) Pistol Grip aluminium pack. A 2013 Jaguar XKR, ‘LF62 LCG’ comes to sale straight from Japan, a country renowned for treating its cars properly – and not using salt on the roads.
The result is a car that displays “zero corrosion” according to the seller. It’s also in “totally original condition, is virtually unmarked, and has a full service history.” It is also ULEZ-compliant and outfitted to the full UK specification.
Hyperbole or fact? Let’s find out, shall we?
exterior:
Obviously, its aluminium construction rules out the sort of widespread rot and rust that killed so many Jaguars in the past, and yet alloy can still corrode although not on this one.
Recently polished and ceramic coated, the colour gives the XKR a hewn-from-solid look the ultra-sharp shutlines reinforce. Jaguar had had seven years to get its eye in by the time it built this one, and that experience shows.
The coachwork is further enhanced with the ‘Dynamic R’ styling package and other exterior treats include Active Headlamps. The seller has also fitted the full-size, UK-spec numberplate plinths.
The 20-inch Nevis alloy wheels – 8.5-inches wide at the front and an inch wider on the rear axle – are not only resplendent with no dinks, scrapes or other damage, they’re also fitted with matching Dunlop SP Sport Maxx tyres.
As with the width of the wheels the sizes differ with the rear sitting on 275/40ZR20 and the front resting on 255/35ZR20. Jaguar did the job properly in the first place and it’s nice to see it’s been maintained with the same diligence; we will never get tired of telling you that experience shows that matching high-quality tyres are an infallible sign of a caring and mechanically sympathetic owner who is prepared to spend the appropriate amount in maintaining their car properly.
The design of the wheels also allows you to admire the upgraded braking package with its grey calipers.
As for flaws, our in-house assessor was being very picky when he inspected the car, identifying the following: a couple of really light scratches on the front nearside wheelarch that most people wouldn't notice; some crazing to both headlight covers; a tiny mark in the middle on of the passenger door; a touched-in chip and small scratch on the offside rear wheelarch; a couple of light marks on the edge of the driver’s door and a small chip at the bottom; and a tiny touch-up next to the driver’s door.
He concluded his examination by saying that “it is a very clean exterior with the usual small stonechips and some light paint swirling to some panels if the light catches it right.”
mechanical:
The XKR has a full service history, something that’s usually hard to prove with Japanese cars as they take GDPR so seriously they tend to remove any paperwork that has a previous owner’s details on it.
This example is also showing 66,000 miles on the odometer, a figure that’s supported by a mileage verification certificate as well as the aforementioned paperwork.
As you can see, the supercharged five-litre V8 engine starts with a subdued snarl, howls when provoked, and leaves schoolchild bleeding from their ears in its wake.
The seller reports that it drives “like new”; our man is more reserved, but given he reports that “it drives well with no faults that we noticed” means we’re actually probably aligned on the subject.
It is due a service though, so you should factor in the cost of that into your bidding strategy.
The engine bay is as impressively clean as every other aspect of the car, and we can’t see many people finding a need to improve and clean it further.
As for the underside, we’re constantly amazed at how well cars from Japan survive – and how strong is the contrast between them and cars that have lived through a dozen or more British winters.
With an aluminium frame structural corrosion is never going to be an issue but the fact the steel fasteners, brackets, and other components aren’t crusted
and seized with rust is a revelation that your local garage will thank you for every time they service or repair it; we often see a surcharge on invoices for having to spend extra time removing rusty nuts and bolts, but we doubt the lucky new owner of this XKR ever will.
Top tip: If you apply a Waxoyl or Lanoguard coating the underside will stay this good indefinitely. It’ll be a small investment, but one we’d urge you to consider given how clean it all is under here.
History:
The XKR’s MoT certificate is valid until October 2024 and, as you’d expect of such a well-maintained example, it was issued with no advisories.
The recent Vehicle History Check is clear bar the marker for being an imported car, and it comes with one key fob.
Its history file includes the owner’s handbook and book pack, the jaguar wallet, a mileage verification certificate, and the full service history.
There’s also an invoice on file for £1,500 for polishing the Jaguar and adding the UK-spec components, which is a nice touch that enables you to see exactly what’s been done.
As we mentioned before, it’s ULEZ-compliant, will cost you just £345 a year to tax, and you shouldn’t face any loading on your insurance premium either.
